column1: Cystoscopy is a procedure to see the inside of the bladder and urethra using a telescope.
Cystoscopy is performed with a cystoscope -- a special tube with a small camera on the end (endoscope).
- Check for cancer of the bladder or urethra - Diagnose and evaluate urinary tract disorders - Diagnose the cause of repeated bladder infections - Help determine the cause of pain during urination

- Bladder stones (calculi) - Bladder wall decompression - Chronic urethritis - Congenital (present at birth) abnormality - Cysts - Diverticula - Irritable bladder - Polyps - Prostate problems, such as bleeding, enlargement, or blockage - Traumatic injury of the bladder and urethra - Tumors - Ulcer - Urethral strictures
Drink 4 - 6 glasses of water per day after your cystoscopy.
